text.tspan: creates apps in his spare time

flowRoot.flowPara: Mikko is building an application that gives suggestions what clothes to wear. It needs to know the weather forecast and he wonders how he can get that data.

Mikko googles "weather forecast data" and finds some information. Then he googles "weather api" and finds more options. Finally he googles "best weather api" and finds a link to apinf.io "weather" category
Mikko wants to build something useful.
It's a side project so how can Mikko be as efficient as possible?
Limited amount of time, no budget
API catalog filtered on a specific category.
Mikko finds many options and wants to know which one to pick.
How can you find out which API to trust?
Making a choice is hard
Surprised by the amount of choice
Eager to get started - optimistic
The link leads Mikko to the category "weather" of APIs on apinf.io, ranked by score (popularity & quality). He can see all the weather APIs and gets the basic information about each in the catalog.

Mikko clicks on the most popular weather API and reads the first page with more info. He finds other information on that page too, such as projects using the API, code examples, blog posts, changelog,... He skims this information and remembers to come back to it later.
He finds the option to try out the API by clicking a button. He plays around a bit with different requests and responses.
He likes that he can play with it immediatly, it gives him a first feel of how the API works and that it actually is up and running.

Mikko still goes back to the catalog (list of APIs) and quickly browses #2 and #3 of the APIs, but decides to give the first API a try in his app, since it seemed to do the job. He feels he can trust this API and the fact that other devs have used it succesfully creates some trust.

When Mikko made a choice to use a certain API, there are clear instructions how to proceed. He is briefly interupted to sign-up, but he reads that an account is required to obtain an API key. He also reads that this key can be used for any API on apinf.io and likes it that he can manage all APIs he might use in the future in one place.
After signup, Mikko receives his API key. With the help of code examples and incorporating the generated SDK, he manages to make a first test call from within his application within 30 minutes.
More presence on Google through SEO. Currently top results include blog post from programmableweb.com
Learns the best search term for data is API

text.tspan: GOALS: Build an app that provides value with least effort

flowRoot.flowPara: He continues building the application and totally forgets about apinf.io until he wants to add more weather-related functionality. He remembers the docs hosted on apinf.io and finds the answers to his questions there.
Luckily he had bookmarked the API so he could find it immediatly.
Strong SEO allows users to use google to find good sources on apinf.io
A catalog of APIs ranked in a sensible way. There is a grouping on the category "weather".
API detail view provides basic insights and useful content.
APIs can be tried out, so users get a feel on how it works (and that it actually does work).
Learn more about how other users have integrated this API.
Signing up in order to obtain an API key, which can be used for any of the APIs on the apinf.io platform.
Clear documentation explains the functionality of the API and gives all the needed information to incorporate the API in your own app.
Code examples and SDKs help users with rapidly making their first call from within the application they develop.
Bookmarks help users find the APIs they are interested in (or are using). Documentation is organized logically so finding the required information is easy.
Strong metadata shows good info on google search results.
API detail view
API documentation and interaction functions.
API catalog filtered on a specific category.
Signup form.
API documentation and interaction functions.
API metadata: SDKs, code examples, blog posts,...
API bookmarks - personal data.
Mikko wants to explore: what type of information does he get and will this help him reach his goal?
Mikko makes a choice. He feels that the time he will invest to continue with his choice of API will be worth it. If it turns out that he needs another API, he can always come back and try another.
Mikko starts to implement the API within his app.
Mikko needs more functionality from the API.
What type of information do you get from an API on this new apinf.io platform?
Does this API even work?
Is the top ranked indeed the best API for my use case?
How do I use this API in my app?
How can I get back to this API later on, as fast as possible?
There is too much information and I don't know yet what exactly I will need.
Giving your trust is not easy to something you don't know.
Signup. People don't like it.
It's not clear how exactly I need to use this API in my app.
Why stay on the platform and not go straight to the source? The source is always up to date.
Exploring about the platform
Feels like trying out and experimenting.
Curious to see what the other APIs offer
A little bit annoyed, but comprehensive nonetheless.
Pleasantly surprised, because he gets a benefit he wasn't expecting.
A bit in a hurry, as he is "in the flow". He wants to get back to his IDE.
Learns about the most popular APIs.
Learns about what apinf.io offers.
Learns that this API works as expected.
Dives into the API docs and learns more about this specific API.
Learns about the "management" functions of apinf.io. He can get an overview of all bookmarked APIs.
Implement categories and have sensible taxonomy.
More APIs with good data.
Better ranking.
Make detail view more attractive, with better content.
Make the "try out" more prominent. Now it's hidden.
Explain benefits of signing up better.
Better instructions, more code examples and content.
Better management design for API users.
